Name: 2-METHYLNAPHTHALENE
Description: 2-methylnaphthalene is a methylnaphthalene carrying a methyl substituent at position 2.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Howsam A et al; Environ Pollut 108: 413-24 (2000)
plant_concentrations.Value: 2-Methylnaphthalene concentrations in oak, ash and hazel leaves from Meathrop Wood, UK were all <0.01 ng/sq cm; samples were collected from 6 sites in Aug 1995(1).

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Afolabi OA et al; J Agric Food Chem 31: 1083-90 (1983)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: In Nigeria, African mudfish (Clarias lazera), Tilapia sp. (Sarotherodon niloticus), Tilapia sp. (Sarotherodon galileus), Tilapia sp. (Tilapia zilli) and Hemichromis fasiatus fish are cured for preservation(1). 2-Methylnaphthalene concentrations were measured for 4 of these preservation methods; traditional smoking (TS), traditional solar drying (TD), oven drying (OD) and Ife solar drying (ISD). Results are reported in ng/g dry fish(1):

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Vassilaros DL et al; Anal Chem 54: 106-12 (1982) (2) Pereira WE et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 15: 172-80 (1996) (3) Merriman  JC et al; Chemosphere 23: 1605-15 (1991) (4) Easton MDL et al; Chemosphere 46: 1053-74 (2002) (5) Norena-Barroso E et al; Mar Pollut Bull 38: 637-45 (1999)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Bullhead catfish (Ictalurus nebulosus) from the Black River and Lake  Buckeye, OH and striped bass from the Potomac River, MD contained 2-methylnaphthalene at 6, 5 and 1 ppb, respectively(1). 2-Methylnaphthalene concentrations in samples of the bivalve Corbicula fluminea from the San  Joaquin River, CA and its tributaries in 1992 were <0.5 ng/g at three of the four sites sampled and 0.6 ng/g at Dry Creek(2). 2-Methylnaphthalene was not detected (detection limit 10.0 ng/g) in five of the six composite fish samples of juvenile fish, yellow perch (Perca  flavescens), logperch (Percina caprodes) and smallmouth bass (Micropterus dolomieuui), collected from the Rainy River on the Ontario, Canada and Minnesota boarder in Aug 1988, upstream and downstream from two bleached kraft mills that discharged directly into this river(3). The 2-methylnaphthalene concentration in a logperch sample collected 5 km downstream from the mill discharges was 15.1 ng/g(3). 2-Methylnaphthalene was detected in farm raised and wild salmon collected 1999 and 2000 from Canada and the US(4). 2-Methylnaphthalene concentrations in American oyster (Crassostrea virginica) were 147-288, 142-163, 96.4-127, 114-388 and 67.5-252 ng/g dry weight in samples collected from Atasta, Chica, Pargo, Chumpan and Chacahito locations of Terminos Lagoon, Mexico, respectively; samples were collected Feb to July 1991(5).

Mussels (Mytilus galloprovincialis), were translocated from 20 miles off the coast of Marina de Ravenna in the Adriatic Sea to locations in 3 coastal lagoons of Ravenna, Italy(1). The concentration of 2-methylnaphthalene was measured before and after 30 days of relocation with the following results (all concentrations are in ng/g dry weight)(1):
fish_seafood_concentrations.Table: [{'Location': 'BAI2', 'Soil Concn': 23, 'Mussel Concn Day 0': 20, 'Mussel Concn Day 30': '7.8'}, {'Location': 'BAC1', 'Soil Concn': 18, 'Mussel Concn Day 0': 20, 'Mussel Concn Day 30': '24'}, {'Location': 'BAC5', 'Soil Concn': 18, 'Mussel Concn Day 0': 20, 'Mussel Concn Day 30': '17'}, {'Location': 'MAG5', 'Soil Concn': 750, 'Mussel Concn Day 0': 20, 'Mussel Concn Day 30': 'all mussels died'}]

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Bedient PB et al; Ground Water 22: 318-29 (1984) (2) Aislabie J et al; Chemosphere 39: 2201-7 (1999)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: At a Conroe, TX creosote waste facility, soil contained 2-methylnaphthalene at 3.42, 0.44, 0.11 and 0.03 mg/kg at depths of 0.7-1.8, 5, 10 and 24-25 m, respectively(1). Soils collected from 3 contaminated sites in the Ross Dependency, Antarctica contained 2-methylnaphthalene at 160, 804, and 442 ng/g dry weight at depths of 0-2, 2-10 and 20-30 cm, respectively, at a drum storage location, and at 370 and 3015 ng/g dry weight at depths of 0-2 and 5-15 cm, respectively, at a generator location at Scott Base(2). At Marble Point, 2-methylnaphthalene concentrations were 53, <30 and <30 ng/g dry weight at 0-2, 5-10 and 20-30 cm at the former base(2). At Wright Valley, 2-methylnaphthalene concentrations were <30 ng/g dry weight at 0-5 cm and 436 ng/g dry weight at 0-5 cm at Vanda Station from 2 spill locations(2). Background samples were taken at all 3 sites with 2-methylnaphthalene concentrations of <30 ng/g dry weight(2).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Pruell RJ, Quinn JG; Toxicol Environ Chem 10: 183-200 (1985) (2) Phillips CR et al; Mar Environ Res 22: 33-75 (1987) (3) Chan CH; Water Pollut Res J Can 28: 451-471 (1993) (4) Iannuzzi TJ et al;  Chemosphere 34: 213-231 (1997) (5) Merriman JC et al; Chemosphere 23:  1605-15 (1991) (6) Hawthorne SB et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 25: 2901-11 (2006) (7) Klecka G et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 207: 1-93 (2010) (8) White HK et al; Environ Sci Technol 9: 8273-80 (2005)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Sediments from Providence River, Mid-bay and Rhode Island Sound, RI contained 2-methylnaphthalene at an average of 44.9, 11.5 and 2.5 ng/g, respectively(1). Sediment from George's Bank contained 2-methylnaphthalene at an average of 1.69 ng/g(2). Suspended sediment was collected 1987 to 1989 from the head and mouth of the St. Clair River, which runs between Ontario Canada and Michigan; 2-methylnaphthalene concentrations were 7.22-770.2 and 10.77-5435 ng/g with a mean of 139.2 and 197.9 ng/g at Point  Edward (head) and at Port Lambton (mouth), respectively(3). Ten surficial sediment samples were collected adjacent to each of four combined sewer overflow (CSO) outfalls along the lower Passaic River in New Jersey; 2-Methylnaphthalene was detected in 80% of the samples from the Ivy Street CSO area with a  median concentration of 220 ug/kg, and in 0-10% of the samples from the other three CSO areas(4). 2-Methylnaphthalene was not detected in suspended solids (detection limit 10.0 ng/g) from four stations along the Rainy River on the Ontario, Canada and Minnesota boarder in samples collected Jun and Aug 1988(5). 2-Methylnaphthalene concentration in suspended solids from the Rainy River where final effluent from two bleached kraft mills discharge directly into the river were 12.0-126 ng/g(5). 2-Methylnaphthalene was detected in sediment samples from 114 sites from 8 historically contaminated locations in New York and North Carolina at 0.01-559 ug/g; samples were collected 2003 to 2005(6). Pore water concentrations of 2-methylnaphthalene from 88 of these samples were not detected to 1288 ng/g(6). 2-Methylnaphthalene was detected in 18 of 18 sediment samples collected from US streams in the Great Lakes basin from Apr to June 2006 at 10-50 ng/g dry weight(7). 2-Methylnaphthalene was not detected in the 0-2 or 28-30 cm segment of a sediment core sample from Wild Harbor, West Falmouth, MA sampled Aug 2000, but was detected in the 14-16 cm at 0.013 ug/g(8).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Huntley SL et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 51: 865-72 (1993)

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Varanasi U et al; Environ Sci Technol 4: 721-6 (1985) (2) Malins DC et al; Carcinogenesis  6: 1463-9 (1985) (3) Shinohara R et al; Environ Internat 4: 163-74  (1980) (4) Malins DC et al; Environ Sci Technol 18: 705-13 (1984) (5) Bieri R et al; Intern J  Environ Anal Chem 26: 97-113 (1986) (6) Pereira WE et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 15: 172-80 (1996) (7) Pereira WE et al; Mar Chem 64: 99-113 (1999) (8) Echols KR et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 55: 161-72 (2008)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Sediment from the Duwamish River delta, WA contained 2-methylnaphthalene at an average concentration of 90 ng/g(1). Sediments from three sites in Eagle Harbor and one at President Point, WA contained 2-methylnaphthalene at an average of 110, 1700, 23 and <3.5 ng/g for 4, 9, 2 and 1 sample(s), respectively(2). 2-Methylnaphthalene was also detected in sediments from Dohkai Bay(3) and Puget Sound, WA(4), and the Elizabeth River, VA(5). 2-Methylnaphthalene concentrations in bed sediments and suspended solids from the San Joaquin River, CA and its tributaries in 1992 were 0.6-1.7 and 1.1-12 ng/L, respectively(6). 2-Methylnaphthalene concentrations in a sediment core from Richardson Bay and San Pablo Bay in San Francisco Bay, CA ranged from 1.6 ng/g dry weight at 138-148 cm up to 17 ng/g dry weight at 20-30 cm and from 2.1 ng/g dry weight at 140-150 cm to 14 90-120 cm, respectively(7). Sediment samples from the lower Missouri river (Omaha, NB to Jefferson City, MO) were collected Oct 28 to Nov 6, 2002; 2-methylnaphthalene concentrations were 1.8-103 ng/g(8).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Bertolotto RM et al; Mar Pollut Bull 46: 903-17 (2003) (2) Guo W et al; Chemosphere 68: 93-104 (2007) (3) Ou S et al; Chemosphere 56: 107-12 (2004) (4) Kawata K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 75: 546-53 (2005)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: 2-Methylnaphthalene was detected in 12 sediment samples collected in 1998 from the northern part of the Ligurian Sea, Italy at less than detection limit to 3040 ug/kg(1). Sediment samples taken from the Hun, Taizi and Daliao rivers in China contained 1.26-20.20, 1.93-6.82 and 3.80-13.74 ng/g dry weight of 2-methylnaphthalene, respectively; samples were collected Aug 2005(2). 2-Methylnaphthalene was detected in 11 of 11 sediment samples collected from Xiamen Harbour and Yuan Dan Lake, China at 0.3-57.8 ng/g; samples were collected Apr 2002(3). 2-Methylnaphthalene was detected at 1.2-14 ng/g dry weight in sediment samples from 4 rivers and 1 port in Niigata, Japan; samples were collected Nov-Dec 1999(4).
